titleStmt.title: The mechanical and oxidation properties of novel B2-ordered Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x refractory high-entropy alloys

analytic.title: The mechanical and oxidation properties of novel B2-ordered Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x refractory high-entropy alloys

biblStruct.note: Received 8 May 2021; Received in revised form 14 June 2021; Accepted 27 June 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory high-entropy alloys Ordered structure Mechanical properties Oxidation performance

div.p: A series of novel B2-ordered Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) was designed and prepared by vacuum arc-melting. The effect of Al alloying on the microstructure, mechanical properties, and oxidation properties was investigated. The Al addition triggers the transformation of the crystal structure from disordered BCC phase to ordered B2 phase, and the Al1 alloy present single B2 phase structure. This B2 ordering results in significant yield strength increase of the RHEAs, i.e., from 915 MPa to 1410 MPa at room temperature (RT, leading to an excellent specific strength of ~232.3 KPa⋅m 3 /kg for the Al1 alloy), 719 MPa to 1088 MPa at 873 K and 126 MPa to 278 MPa at 1073 K, respectively. However, in the expense, the near full and full B2structured Al0.75 and Al1 alloys show dramatic reduction in compressive ductility down to 31.4% and 15.1% at RT. Four parameters, VEC, ΔH mix , Bo and Md are employed to predict the B2 ordering in the RHEAs, and the calculation shows that ordered phases are preferred in the realm of ΔH mix < -14 kJ⋅mol -1 and Bo < 0.4Md+1.9. In addition, the introducing of Al also significantly enhances the oxidation resistance of the alloys. While the Al0 alloy shows catastrophic oxidation within 24 h in air at 1073 K, the Al1 alloy only gains 112 mg⋅cm -2 after 50 h. However, the constitution of the oxide layer remains loose and complex, consisting of multiple oxides including Al 2 O 3 , TiO 2 , (Zr,Hf)O 2 and (Zr,Hf)V 2 O 7 .

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The development of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) or complex concentrated alloys (CCAs) challenges the traditional alloying strategy consisting of only one or two predominant elements [1,2]. The greatly broadened alloy composition space by the idea of HEAs results in unexpected solid-solution related structures and hence outstanding integrated properties, which attracts growing attentions in the material science community over the past decades [3][4][5][6][7][8]. Refractory highentropy alloys (RHEAs) are an important group of HEAs that mainly consist of refractory elements. These elements render RHEAs body centered cubic (BCC) or hexagonal close-packed (HCP) structure with high strength and hardness, decent ductility and excellent corrosion resistance [9][10][11], thereinto, the high and soften resistance at elevated temperatures are the most potential advantage [12][13][14]. For example, WMoTaNb(V) can retain over 500 MPa at 1600 • C [15], yet their high density, room temperature (RT) brittleness, and poor oxidation resistance greatly limits the application potential of these W/Mo contained RHEAs [16,17]. In the consideration of a good balance of strength, ductility, density, and oxidation resistance, antioxidant elements with low density, e.g., Al, Cr, Si are usually added in RHEAs. These newly designed RHEAs include AlMo 0.5 NbTa 0.5 TiZr, AlTiVCr, AlNbTiVZr x , (Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi)/M 5 Si 3 and AlCr x NbTiV [18][19][20][21][22][23][24], with densities in the range of 5.0 to 8.4 g/cm 3 and specific strengths superior to Ni-based superalloys, yet the ductility lose remains without decent improvement. This can be attributed to the formation of brittle intermetallic phases, i. e., B2 phase in the case of Al addition [25][26][27], Cr 2 M Laves phase in the case of Cr addition [22,28,29], and M 5 Si 3 silicide in the case of Si addition [21,30], respectively. While B2 phase keeps a coherent interface with the BCC matrix which totally differs from the other two intermetallic phases, the ductility loss of the Al-RHEAs can be the lowest, with compressive ductility >10%.

For oxidation performance of RHEAs, however, limited studies are carried out to date. Liu et al. investigated the oxidation properties of a series of Nb-Cr-Mo-Al-Ti/V/Si RHEAs with different content of Ti, V, and Si in early years [31]. They found that the oxidation resistance of the RHEAs was improved with Ti and Si addition, but deteriorated with V addition. Gorr et al. studied the oxidation performances of TaMoCrTiAl, WMoCrTiAl, NbMoCrTiAl(Si) RHEAs, all showing mass gain below 10 mg/cm 2 at 1000 • C and 1100 • C for 40 h and oxidation kinetics of parabolic pattern except NbMoCrTiAl [32][33][34][35]. Bulter et al. systematically investigated the oxidation properties of TiZrNbV/TiZrNbCr and Al 20 Nb 30 Ta 10 Ti 30 Zr 10 RHEAs [36,37]. TiZrNbV HEA presents a nearlinear oxidation kinetic curve, while those of TiZrNbCr and Al 20 Nb 30- Ta 10 Ti 30 Zr 10 RHEAs are parabolic, with the mass gain of about 106 mg/ cm 2 and 40 mg/cm 2 respectively, after 100 h of oxidation at 1000 • C. Due to the nature of compositional complex, these RHEAs form oxide layers with multiple complicated oxides that are different from traditional alloys, i.e., single, or a simple mix of the three classical oxides Al 2 O 3 , Cr 2 O 3 and SiO 2 . The jointly formation and complex distribution of these oxides in the oxide layers such as NbAlO 4 , ZrO 2 , Ti 7 Al 2 O 15 , Ta 2 Nb 4 O 15 . TiNb 2 O 7 , TiO 2 , Nb 2 Zr 6 O 17 seems therefore responsible for the reported poor oxidation resistance. Although the heavy addition of Al and/or Cr would greatly improve the oxidation capacity of RHEA, their mechanical properties are inevitably sacrificed, in particular resulting in poor ductility at RT. Further studies focusing on the balance between the oxidation and mechanical properties are still urgently needed.

Our previous studies presented a successful design of a single BCC structure Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 RHEA with a relatively low density of 6.67 g/ cm 3 [38]. Moreover, it exhibits excellent RT mechanical properties, with compression yield strength of 1000 MPa and ductility over 50%. Based on this RHEA and following the idea of balancing oxidation and mechanical properties, in this work, we additionally introduced alloying of Al in the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 RHEA, in another words, designed a new series of Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs, and systematically investigated the microstructure evolution and the corresponding mechanical responses at RT. In particular, we happened to find that when x increases to 1, the crystalline structure changes to full B2, an ordered intermetallic phase, which strongly influenced the mechanical behavior. The performances at elevated temperatures including oxidation and compression, were also involved, with the detailed corrosion and deformation mechanisms briefly assessed in the following.

div.head: Material and methods
div.p: Novel series of Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs with various amounts of Al addition (simply denoted as Al0, Al0.25, Al0.5, Al0.75, Al1, respectively) were prepared by vacuum arc melting under a Ti-gettered argon atmosphere on a water-cooled copper crucible. Raw metals of Ti, Zr, V, Nb, Al with purity of 99.95 wt% and Hf with purity of 99.5 wt% were used. The ingots were flipped and remelted at least seven times to assure chemical homogeneity. All samples were cut by electric discharge machining, prepared by grinding, polishing in diamond suspension, and cleaned by ultrasound before further experiments.

The crystal structure was identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD, EMPYREAN) using Cu-Ka radiation target operated at 40 kV and 40 mA, and the angles of 2θ scanning was from 20 • to 100 • with a scanning rate of 4 • /min. The microstructure characterization as well as the chemical composition was carried out by electron probe microanalyzer (EPMA, JXA-8530F PLUS) and scanning electron microscaopy (SEM, Zeiss Supra 55). More details of microstructure at nano-scale were revealed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20), and the specimens for TEM were prepared by a dual-beam focused ion beam (FIB, Helios G4UX, Thermo Fisher Scientific USA) instrument.

Compression tests (test standards: ASTM E9-09) were conducted on cylindrical specimens with the dimension of Φ6 × 9 mm using a Wippermann (WPM) materials testing machine at room temperature and a dynamic thermal simulation testing machine (Gleeble-1500D) at high temperatures (873 K and 1073 K), respectively. The strain rate was set at 1 × 10 -3 /s. During high temperature test, the specimens were first heated to the testing temperature at a heating rate of 5 K/s and held for 10 min before loading. Vickers hardness (test standards used ASTM: E384-11e1) was measured using a Vickers hardness tester (MH-50). The loading force is 1000 g and the loading time is 15 s. The measurements were repeated seven times on each sample. The density of the series alloys was measured by the Archimedes drainage method (Mettler-ME204E balance with precision of 0.0001 g).

Isothermal oxidation tests were conducted at 1073 K and exposed to static laboratory air. The dimensions of the prepared samples were 10 × 10 × ~3 mm after surface grinding down to 2000-grits. Mass gain of the oxidation samples was measured using a high sensitivity balance (0.0001 g) and recorded from 1 h to 50 h. Three samples for each time interruption were used to ensure data accuracy. The phase constitutions and microstructures of the oxidized samples were investigated by XRD and EPMA.

div.head: Phase identification and microstructure
div.p: Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction profiles of the as-cast Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs. Only single disordered BCC phase peaks can be found in Al0, Al0.25 and Al0.5 alloys in Fig. 1(a), while in the RHEAs with higher Al content, i.e., Al0.75 and Al1 alloys, minor peaks belonging to the B2 crystal identified as the (100) B2 , (111) B2 and (210) B2 appear. This suggests that the Al addition triggers the B2-type ordering in the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 RHEA that show basically BCC crystalline structure. Fig. 1(b) shows the details of the XRD profiles from 25 to degree. The pattern is smooth without any extra weak peaks beside those above from B2 and BCC. The lattice parameters were calculated decreasing from 3.3655 Å to 3.3269 Å as the Al content increases from x = 0 to x = 1.0. This could be roughly attributed to the smaller atom radius of Al (1.43 Å) compared to the average atomic radius (1.437 Å) of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 matrix.
Fig. 2 presents the microstructures of the as-cast Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs. Fig. 2(a)-(e) are the low magnification BSE images while Fig.

(f)-(j) are at higher magnification. Interestingly, typical dendritic morphology prevails in the alloy series regardless of the Al addition and in particular, the presence of B2-ordering. The only visual change lies on the size of the dendrite arm. With the increase of Al content, the primary dendrite becomes thinner, and the secondary dendrite increase and become more directional. The BSE contrast difference between dendrite (d-dark) and interdendrite (id-light) in these images also indicates the occurrence of the dendritic elemental redistribution during solidification, which is listed in the Table 1. We find that although the composition deviation between dendrite and interdendrite becomes stronger with the addition of Al, the intensity of this derivation is still quite weak, no larger than 4 at.%, agreeing well with the weak BSE contrast.

In order to clarify the possible B2/BCC phase transitions, we present TEM observations of Al0, Al0.25, and Al0.5 alloys firstly in Fig. 3 (d), respectively, the darker phase in Fig. 4(a) can be identified with ordered B2 structure, while the lighter phase is of disordered BCC structure. We probed the composition of the two phases by EDS as also listed in Fig. 4(a), surprisingly, no significant compositional deviations exist. In order to more clearly reveal the differences in composition of the two regions, the TEM-EDS elemental mapping is also tested shown in Fig. 5, no difference in composition can be observed obviously. This supports the conjecture given above that the two phases form in an interbedded manner, in which rearrangement of the local atoms in the cubic lattice occurs and quickly develops into nanoscale domains without apparent long-range elemental diffusion. With the addition of Al element, the short-range ordering area of the alloys increases, and then the area of the B2 phase increases.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: The RT compressive engineering stress-strain curves are depicted in Fig. 6(a), and the extracted yield strength (σ y ) and hardness values as function a of the Al addition, i.e., x, in the present RHEAs are given in Table 2 and described in Fig. 6(b). As x increases from 0 to 1, σ y exhibit a significant increase, from 915 MPa to 1410 MPa, i.e., around 54%. The hardness of the RHEAs shows similar linear increment as a function of x, as evidenced in Fig. 6(b). Moreover, if the unit of hardness is converted to MPa, it can be found that the hardness of the series alloys approximately triples their yield strength. And the average ratio of hardness to strength is φ = HV/σ y = 3.16. it is close to the value of φ ≈ 3, which is the common proportional relationship for pure metals and commercial alloys [44]. The compressive fracture strain (ε f ) remains over 50% when x ≤ 0.5, however, it dramatically decreases to 31.5% and 15.1% in the Al0.75 and Al1 alloys, respectively. In addition, the series of Al-modified RHEAs show much higher specific yield strength (SYS) when compared with other reported RHEAs due to the sharp decrease of density from 6.68 g/cm 3 to 6.07 g/cm 3 as the addition of light-weight element Al. Detailed analysis can be found in the following discussion section. The high temperature compression engineering stress-strain curves of Al0, Al0.5 and Al1 alloys at 873 K and 1073 K are shown in Fig. 7(a) and (b), with the extracted parameters including σ y , ε f and SYS listed in Table 3. Similar to the case at RT, the addition of Al in the RHEA prominently rises σ y at both temperatures, from 710 MPa to 1088 MPa at 873 K and from 126 MPa to 278 MPa at 1073 K, respectively. Noticing that the Al1 alloy can maintain a yield strength over 1 GPa at 873 K, higher than many other RHEAs [21,53,[67][68][69][70]. Fig. 7(c) shows the histogram of the yield strength change at different temperatures. The high strength of the three alloys indicates that the alloys exhibit resistance to softening up to 873 K.

div.head: Oxidation properties
div.p: The isothermal oxidation kinetic curve of a metallic material can be usually described in the form of Power law [74]:

where Δm is mass gain per unit surface area (mg/cm 2 ), t is the holding time (h), k is the oxide growth rate constant, and n is the time exponent. This Eq. ( 1) can be transformed to a linear relationship:

where the slope is the time exponent (n). 4. The alloy without Al (Al0 alloy) clearly exhibit a linear oxidation behavior (n = 1.04) with k = 11.65 mg/(cm 2 ⋅h), suggesting that no oxide film formed on the Al0 alloy. As a consequence, the Al0 alloy suffered catastrophic oxidation after 24 h exposure. In contrast, the oxidation mass gain (Δm) of both the Al0.5 and Al1 alloys was notably decreased, and the oxidation kinetics can be divided into two parts according to the Log/Log curves in Fig. 8(b). Before 24 h, both the two curves obey the parabolic

div.head: Table 2
div.p: Mechanical properties of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x alloys: yield strength (σ y / MPa), plastic strain (ε f /%), fracture strength (σ b /MPa), Vickers hardness (HV/ MPa), density (ρ/g⋅cm -3 ) and specific yield strength (SYS/KPa⋅m 3 ⋅kg -1 ). law, and the fitted n values of Al 0.5 and Al1 alloys is 0.62 and 0.67, respectively, indicating of possible oxygen protection mechanism functioned on the Al0.5 and Al1 alloys before 24 h. However, after 24 h, the oxidation kinetic curves changed towards linear relationship, indicating the loss of the protection ever since. Fig. 9(a) and (b) present the macroscopic morphology as well as the cross-sectional microstructure evolution during oxidation. Oxidation samples, with different Al contents (x = 0, 0.5, 1) and different heat exposure time (10 h, 24 h, and 50 h) are selected. Notice the Al0 alloy is oxidized throughoutly after 24 h. For all the three RHEAs after oxidation over 10 h, cracking and warping occurred in the oxide layer from the bulk edges. The increase in Al content greatly suppressed such phenomenon, leaving the oxide layers much more completed in the Al1 alloy even after 50 h oxidation. From Fig. 9(b), we found that the Al0 alloy shows an oxidation depth of over 590 μm after only 10 h oxidation, while that of Al0.5 and Al1 alloys are much lesser, i.e., 384 μm and 363 μm, respectively. The thickness of the oxide film on the Al0.5 alloy increases to 900 μm and 1475 μm for 24 h and 50 h, while that of the Al1 alloy increases to 718 μm and 1350 μm for 24 h and 50 h, suggesting an overall better oxidation resistance of the Al1 alloy compared to the Al0.5 alloy. In support of this, we observe multiple cracks in the oxide layers of Al0.5 alloy after 10 and 24 h oxidation, and these cracks grow and finally join into larger cracks when further oxidized for 50 h. On the contrary, no cracks exist in the Al1 alloy after 10 and 24 h oxidation while the cracks after 50 h oxidation are obviously smaller. This finding seems agree with the oxidation kinetic results in Fig. 8(b), and suggests that the sudden change of the oxidation response is directly related to the formation of the cracks in the oxidation film that breaks down the protection layer and leads to the catastrophic oxidation.

div.head: Effect of Al addition on the phase evolution
div.p: The formation of ordered B2 phase is of particular interest due to the near-perfect coherency relationship with the major BCC crystalline

div.head: Table 3
div.p: Mechanical properties of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x alloys at RT, 873 K and 1073 K: yield strength (σ y /MPa), plastic strain (ε f /%), and specific yield strength (SYS/KPa⋅m 3 ⋅kg -1 ). structure in RHEAs. Actually to date, most of the reported RHEAs containing, or composed of, B2 phase are alloyed with Al. This is because of the strong directional bonding between atoms of Al, and Ti/Zr, two principal elements in RHEAs, which leads to the B2-type TiAl or ZrAl crystalline structure. In the current RHEA series, it is reasonably to speculate that, the more Al addition, the higher tendency for the B2 phase to form. However, the real questions are, can we precisely predict that at which Al level the B2 phase starts to appear, and how/where the B2 ordering takes place.

Here for the very first question, we applied several frequently-used phase formation criteria including the valence electron concentration (VEC), difference of atomic sizes (δ), mixing enthalpy (ΔH mix ), mixing entropy (ΔS mix ), and Ω -parameter. And the definitions of these criteria are as following [42][43][44]:
div.formula: ΔH mix = ∑ N i=1,j∕ =1 4ΔH mix ij c i c j (5
ΔS mix = -R ∑ n i=1 c i lnc i (6) Ω = T m ΔS mix |ΔH mix |(7)
div.p: where c i and r i are the atomic percentage and the Goldschmidt atomic radius of the ith element, respectively [41]. (VEC) i is the valence electron concentration of element i; H ij mix is an enthalpy of mixing between elements i and j; ΔS mix is the mixing entropy of alloy; T m is the melting point calculated using the rule of mixture.

In general, when in the ranges of -15 kJ/mol < ΔH mix < 5 kJ/mol, δ < 6.6% and Ω ≥ 1.1 [42,43], HEAs tend to present as a solid solution. Also, BCC phase likely shows in HEAs at VEC < 6.87 while FCC phase forms at VEC > 8 [44]. We calculate and list all above parameters of the current RHEAs in Table 5, and plot VEC and ΔH mix values in Fig. 9(a), with reference from other reported BCC HEAs. The VEC values of this RHEA series are all less than 4.3, and decrease with the increase of Al content. This indicates that the Al-RHEAs all prefer a BCC structure. However, Al slight decreases the atomic radius difference, and increases the absolute system enthalpy of the alloys hence decreases Ω, suggesting that beside the BCC main phase, other intermetallic compounds (here is the B2 phase), may form due to the addition of Al, i.e., when ΔH mix < -14 kJ/mol. According to Fig. 9(a) this criterion is in good accordance with the referred BCC HEAs.

We also involve another criterion, i.e., Bo-Md in this study. This criterion is proved effective in phase prediction yet in traditional Ti alloys [45], and most recently in the TiZrHfNb x RHEAs with a decent accuracy [46]. The value of Bo represents the bonding strength of Ti and other alloying elements, and that of Md is mainly related to the electronegativity and metallic radius of elements. The system values of Bo and Md are calculated by rule of mixtures [45]:
div.formula: Bo = ∑ c i Bo i (8) Md = ∑ c i Md i (9)
div.p: where c i is the atomic percentage of the ith element, Bo i and Md i are the values of Bo and Md parameters of element i, respectively. We then plot Bo and Md values of the current RHEAs in Fig. 10(b), again with reference from the same BCC HEAs in Fig. 9(a). We can roughly divide the data in the figure into two parts by a line of Bo=0.4Md+1.9 as marked. RHEAs with the BCC solid solution structure lie in the top left of the graph, while most RHEAs with B2 phase are located in the bottom right. It means that lower Bo and higher Md promote the formation of B2 phase in RHEAs, which seems consistent with the formation rule in Ti alloys.

div.head: The effect of Al elements on the mechanical properties
div.p: As mentioned in the previous results, the addition of Al element significantly increases the strength of the alloys both at RT and high temperatures, regardless the slight decrease in atomic radius difference (δ) (from 5.81% to 5.31%) hence the possible decease of solid-solution hardening. With the addition of Al element, the width of the primary and secondary dendritic arms is all decreased, leading to the reduced dislocation free path. This will certainly yield additional strengthening effect according to the Hall-Petch relationship: σ y = σ 0 + kd -0.5 . where σ y is the yield strength, d is grain size and here can be estimated by the average width of the dendritic arms, σ 0 is a constant that can be considered as the lattice friction resistance, k is a constant related to the material of the alloys and can be referred as 250 MPa⋅μm -1 according to [46,50,51.48,49]. The strength increment caused by the dendritic refinement can be estimated as 29 MPa, which is quite low regarding the total yield strength. Therefore, the high yield strength of the current RHEAs can be mainly attributed to the occurrence of the phase transformation i.e., the B2 ordering. Ordered crystalline structure is generally known stronger than their solid-solution counterparts due to the higher crystalline resistance to dislocation movement, including slip at RT case and climb at high temperature case. Extra driving force is required, and also extra energy has to be consumed, as the formation of a specific kind of fault, APB, when a dislocation shear across the crystal lattice and destroy the perfectly ordered atomic stacking. The APB energy is a parameter representing the difficulty for APB formation in the ordered crystal and therefore indexes the shear resistance for dislocation.

SYS is also important to evaluate the mechanical properties of structural alloys with particular consideration on the light weight of materials. Here we summarized and compared SYS of the current RHEAs series and many different Al/Cr contained RHEAs at RT. The scatter diagram of SYS and density at RT is shown in Fig. 11(a), where the points colored in black indicate the alloys under the as-cast condition, while the points in yellow show the alloys having hot isostatic pressure (HIP) or annealing treatment. Red stars represent the result in this work. It is clear that the current Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x alloys have remarkable high SYS with decent ductility. In addition, more than half of the points are on the left side, indicating of a poor compressive plasticity (<15%). Generally, excessive addition of Al and Cr in the RHEAs will trigger the vast precipitation of intermetallic compounds, which would greatly improve strength but sacrifice most of ductility. For example, the Cr 2 M Laves phase forms in the Ti-contained RHEAs by the addition of Cr. However, in this study no complex compounds formed by the addition of Al to the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x alloy except the B2 ordering. Ordered BCC phase has more slip systems than the complex Laves phase and is coherent with the BCC matrix. As a result, the near full B2 and B2 structured Al0.75 and Al1 alloy show comparable ductility at RT and thus a SYS of 232 KPa⋅m 3 /kg for the Al1 alloy. This suggests that the addition of Al in the RHEAs to trigger coherent ordered phase transformation is a promising design strategy to improve the mechanical response.

We further plot the scatter diagram of SYS and density at 873 K in Fig. 11(b). It is observed that most classical RHEAs without Al show relatively low SYS at this temperature, while those contain Al exhibit relatively high SYS but poor ductility (Mostly less than 10%). We also see that the CoFeNiAl-contained HEAs show either good plasticity or decent SYS. For the three investigated RHEAs in this work, the base Al0 alloy have low specific strength, while after Al addition, their SYSs are greatly improved with ductility larger than 35%. In particular, the SYS of the Al1 alloy can reach to 180 kPa⋅m 3 /kg, outperforming most reported RHEAs at 873 K.

div.head: The effect of Al elements on the oxidation properties
div.p: Fig. 12 shows the XRD patterns of the oxide layers of the Al0, Al0.5 and Al1 alloys after oxidation with different holding times at 1073 K. It indicates that all the three alloys form multiple complex compositional oxides instead of simple single oxide when suffered heat exposure. The oxide layer of Al0 alloy after 10 h oxidation is consisted of TiO 2 , (Zr,Hf) O 2 , (Ti,Zr)Nb 2 O 7 . No V-oxides can be detected, probably due to the formation of V 2 O 5 oxide with low melting point that evaporates at 650 • C or above [73]. Together with the observation in Fig. 8, it can be roughly concluded that the reason for the poor oxidation resistance of the Al0 alloy without Al is: (a) no dense and protective oxide layer formed after oxidation, the oxidation layer of Al0 alloy cannot provide adequate resistance to the ingress of oxygen and was dispersed all throughout the oxide scale; and (b) the escape of the V 2 O 5 oxides from the sample surface that leaves detrimental pores or holes, further accelerating the oxidation process [36]. With the addition of Al, i.e., in the Al0.5 and Al1 alloy, the new diffraction peaks of Al 2 O 3 and (Zr,Hf) V 2 O 7 appears in the XRD patterns after 10 h oxidation as shown in Fig. 11(b), however disappeared again after prolonged oxidation at 24 h and 50 h, as shown in Fig. 11(c). To reveal the detailed elemental information during the formation of the oxide layer in the two alloys, we further plot the elemental mapping of the Al1 sample after 10 h/24 h oxidation in the longitudinal section in Fig. 13. It can be found that the protective oxide Al 2 O 3 is densely distributed on the top of oxide layers these phenomena indicate that the Al0.5/Al1 alloys oxide layers cannot effectively prevent oxidation after prolonged exposure particularly 24 h. This observation is consistent with the oxidation kinetics curves in Section 3.3, where oxidation acceleration begins at 24 h. In summary, the addition of Al element significantly enhances the oxidation resistance of the series alloys and reduces the oxidation weight gain after oxidation, but the effect is so limited and will soon disappear after oxidation with time larger than 24 h. V element is one of the crucial elements responsible for the poor oxidation performance. Further studies are needed to improve the oxidation properties of V-containing RHEAs via building long-term dense and stable protection layer containing multiple complex oxides.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this work, the antioxidant light-weight element Al was added into the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs to improve the mechanical and oxidation properties, with main conclusions can be drawn as following:

1. Al plays a key role in the B2 ordering in the series of RHEAs. The addition of Al triggers the phase transformation in the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs from disordered BCC phase to ordered B2 phase without apparent long-range elemental diffusion. With the increase of Al content, the ordered B2 phase appears in the Al0.5 alloy in a very small range of short-range order, then expand to a large range of long-range order, and finally a single-phase B2 structure when x = 1. Three semi-empirical criteria are used to predict this phase formation, and we found that the B2 ordering starts when ΔH mix < -14 kJ⋅mol -1 , Bo < 0.4Md+1.9. In this paper, the process of transformation from single BCC structure to single B2 structure has been studied in depth. The results not only provide experience for the design of RHEAs with B2 phase in the future, but also shed lights on the potential of structural application at elevated temperature for these RHEAs.

figure.figDesc: Fig.1shows the X-ray diffraction profiles of the as-cast Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs. Only single disordered BCC phase peaks can be found in Al0, Al0.25 and Al0.5 alloys in Fig.1(a), while in the RHEAs with higher Al content, i.e., Al0.75 and Al1 alloys, minor peaks belonging to the B2 crystal identified as the (100) B2 , (111) B2 and (210) B2 appear. This suggests that the Al addition triggers the B2-type ordering in the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 RHEA that show basically BCC crystalline structure. Fig.1(b)shows the details of the XRD profiles from 25 to degree. The pattern is smooth without any extra weak peaks beside those above from B2 and BCC. The lattice parameters were calculated decreasing from 3.3655 Å to 3.3269 Å as the Al content increases from x = 0 to x = 1.0. This could be roughly attributed to the smaller atom radius of Al (1.43 Å) compared to the average atomic radius (1.437 Å) of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 matrix. Fig. 2 presents the microstructures of the as-cast Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs. Fig. 2(a)-(e) are the low magnification BSE images while Fig.(f)-(j) are at higher magnification. Interestingly, typical dendritic morphology prevails in the alloy series regardless of the Al addition and in particular, the presence of B2-ordering. The only visual change lies on the size of the dendrite arm. With the increase of Al content, the primary dendrite becomes thinner, and the secondary dendrite increase and become more directional. The BSE contrast difference between dendrite (d-dark) and interdendrite (id-light) in these images also indicates the occurrence of the dendritic elemental redistribution during solidification, which is listed in the Table1. We find that although the composition deviation between dendrite and interdendrite becomes stronger with the addition of Al, the intensity of this derivation is still quite weak, no larger than 4 at.%, agreeing well with the weak BSE contrast.In order to clarify the possible B2/BCC phase transitions, we present TEM observations of Al0, Al0.25, and Al0.5 alloys firstly in Fig.3, and those of Al0.75 and Al1 alloys in Fig.4. Fig.3(a) and (c) are the bright field (BF) images of Al0 and Al0.25 alloys, respectively. It can be seen that the contrast of the images is uniform. The corresponding selected area diffraction patterns (SADP) taken from red circled regions in Fig.(b) and (d) confirm the single disordered BCC phase structure, with no other phase or B2 ordering exists. Fig.3(e) is the BF images of Al0.5 alloys, similarly showing no significant contrast. However, the SADPs in two different regions along [001] and [011] zone axis, as shown in the insets in Fig.3(f) and (g) together verify the existence of ordered B2 phase. The corresponding dark field images in Fig.3(f) and (g) reveal clearly the uniform and dense distribution of the B2 phase particles with bright contrast, embedding in the BCC matrix. These B2 particles have a mean diameter of 2 nm and a volume fraction of 3.5%. The highresolution (HR) images of the red rectangular region in Fig.3(g) is shown in Fig. 3(h), which indicates the full coherency of the B2 phase and the BCC matrix. Fig. 4(a)-(d) and (e)-(h) display the TEM results of the Al0.75 alloy

figure.head: Fig. 4 (
figure.figDesc: e) is the bright field (BF) image under the [001] zone axis of the Al1 alloy, where only plenty antiphase boundaries (APBs) appear with no other detectable phases or precipitations. This may indicate that the alloy is almost completely ordered. The SADP in Fig.4(f) is almost the same as the B2 superlattice reflections given in Fig.4(b). The high-resolution (HR) images of the rectangular region in Fig.4(e) is shown in Figs. 4(g), and (h) is the magnified HR-image transformed by Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) and inverse Fast Fourier Transform (IFFT) of the square region as marked in Fig.4(g). The inserted FFT diffraction pattern again evidences the strong B2 reflection. Similar APB morphology with B2 superlattice reflection can be found in other pure B2 alloys including TiAl, NiAl and also the earlier report of Ta/MoCrTiAl and TiVNbCr RHEAs, suggesting that here the Al1 alloy is of a pure B2 structure[19,39,40,[41][42][43].

figure.head: Fig. 8 (
figure.figDesc: a) show the fitted oxidation kinetics curves of the Al0, Al0.5 and Al1 alloys, while Fig. 7(b) presents the above curves in a Log/Log scale. The fitted n and k values are listed in the Table

figure.figDesc: Fig. 9. (a) The macro morphology of the Al0, Al0.5 and Al1 alloys being oxidized after different times (10 h, 24 h and 50 h); (b) the cross-BSE images of Al0, Al0.5 and Al1 alloys after oxidation.

figure.head: Fig. 10 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 10. (a) ΔH mix -VEC and (b) Bo -Md scatter diagram of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x alloys and RHEAs from ref. [14,19,20,27,24,39,46,47] -[50-55,56,57,58-65,66-68].

figure.head: Fig. 11 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 11. SYS and ductility of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x alloys (a) at RT and (b) 873 K compared with other reported HEAs[14,[15][16][17][18][19][20]22,24,26,28,30,34,41,[52][53][54][55]56,57,[66][67][68][69][70][71][72].

figure.head: Fig. 12 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 12. XRD patterns of the oxide layers of the alloys that have been oxidized at different times ((a) Al0-10 h; (b)Al0.5/Al1-10 h; (c)Al0.5/1-24 h/50 h).

The Al addition significantly increases the yield strength of the alloy from 915 MPa (x = 0) to 1410 MPa (x = 1.0) at RT without obvious ductility loss due to the B2 type ordering. The Al1 alloy remain high yield strength up to 1088 MPa at 873 K. The greatly reduced density of the RHEAs as the result of Al addition also contributes to the dramatically increase of SYS. The combination of SYS and ductility of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al 1 RHEA is superior to most RHEAs from RT to 873 K. 3. The Al addition reduces oxidation weight gain of the Ti 2 ZrHf 0.5 VNb 0.5 Al x RHEAs from the catastrophic oxidation of Al0 alloy after 24 h, to 112.1 mg⋅cm -2 of Al1 alloy after 50 h oxidation. The oxidation kinetics curves of Al0.5 and Al1 alloys followed the parabolic law before 24 h, but degraded into linear law after 24 h. The reason is attributed to the twisting and cracking of Al 2 O 3 oxide layer and the formation of evaporable oxide V 2 O 5 that accelerate the oxidation process.

figure.head: Fig. 13 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 13. Elemental mapping in the vertical section of the oxide layer after 10 h and 24 h of the Al1 alloys.
